desc.eng: Presence and absence of features, their attributes and their relationships
desc.cat: Presència i absència dels objectes i dels seus atributs i relacions
desc.spa: Presencia y ausencia de los objetos y sus atributos y sus relaciones

desc.eng: Degree of adherence to logical rules of data structure, attribution and relationships (data structure can be conceptual, logical or physical)
desc.spa: Grau d'adhesió a les regles lògiques de l'estructura de dades, atributs i relacions (l'estructura de dades pot ser conceptual, lògica o física)
Grado de adherencia a las reglas lógicas de la estructura de datos, atributos y relaciones (la estructura de datos puede ser conceptual, lógica o física)

desc.eng: Accuracy of the position of features within a spatial reference system
desc.cat: Exactitud de la posició dels objectes dins un sistema de referència espacial
desc.spa: Exactitud de la posición de los objetos en un sistema de referencia espacial

desc.eng: Accuracy of the temporal attributes and temporal relationships of features
desc.cat: Exactitud dels atributs temporals i de les relacions temporals dels objectes
desc.spa: Exactitud de los atributos temporales y de las relaciones temporales de los objetos

desc.eng: Accuracy of quantitative attributes and the correctness of non-quantitative attributes and of the classifications of features and their relationships
desc.cat: Exactitud dels atributs quantitatius i correctesa dels atributs no quantitatius i de la classificació dels objectes i les seves relacions
desc.spa: Exactitud de los atributos cuantitativos y corrección de los atributos no cuantitativos y de las clasificaciones de los objetos y sus relaciones

desc.eng: Degree of adherence of a dataset to a specific set of requirements. Usability is based on user requirements. All quality elements may be used to evaluate usability
desc.cat: Grau d'adhesió d'un conjunt de dades a un conjunt específic de requeriments. La usabilitat es basa en els requisits dels usuaris.  Tots els elements de qualitat es poden utilitzar per avaluar la usabilitat
desc.spa: Grado de adherencia de un conjunto de datos a un conjunto específico de requisitos. La usabilidad se basa en los requisitos del usuario. Todos los elementos de calidad se pueden usar para evaluar la usabilidad

desc.eng: Metaquality elements are a set of quantitative and qualitative statements about a quality evaluation and its result
desc.cat: Els elements de la metaqualitat són un conjunt de declaracions quantitatives i qualitatives sobre una avaluació de la qualitat i el seu resultat
desc.spa: Los elementos de metacalidad son un conjunto de declaraciones cuantitativas y cualitativas sobre un evaluación de calidad y su resultado

desc.cat: Excés de dades presents en el conjunt de les dades, en funció del seu abast o àmbit
desc.eng: Excess data present in the dataset, as described by the scope
desc.spa: Exceso de datos presentes en el conjunto de los datos,  en función de su alcance

desc.cat: Dades absents del conjunt de les dades, en funció del seu abast o àmbit
desc.eng: Data absent from the dataset, as described by the scope

desc.cat: Adherència a les regles de l'esquema conceptual
desc.eng: Adherence to rules of the conceptual schema

name.cat: Consistència dels valors amb el domini de valors
name.spa: Consistencia de los valores con el dominio de valores

desc.cat: Adherència dels valors del domini de valors
desc.eng: Adherence of values to the value domains

desc.cat: Grau a què s'emmagatzemen les dades d'acord amb l'estructura física del conjunt de dades, tal com es descriu per l'àmbit d'aplicació
desc.eng: Degree to which data is stored in accordance with the physical structure of the dataset, as described by the scope
Correctness of the explicitly encoded topological characteristics of the dataset as described by the scope
Closeness of reported coordinate values to values accepted as or being true

name.cat: Exactitud posicional de les cel·les del ràster
name.spa: Exactitud posicional de las celdas del ráster

desc.eng: Closeness of gridded data position values to values accepted as or being true
Closeness of the relative positions of features in the scope to their respective relative positions accepted as or being true

name.cat: Exactitud en la mesura del temps
name.spa: Exactitud en la medida del tiempo

desc.eng: Correctness of the temporal references of an item (reporting of error in time measurement)
Correctness of ordered events or sequences, if reported
Validity of data specified by the scope with respect to time
Comparison of the classes assigned to features or their attributes to a universe of discourse

name.spa: Exactitud de los atributos no cuantitativos

desc.eng: Accuracy of non-quantitative attributes
Accuracy of quantitative attributes
Degree of adherence of a dataset to a specific set of requirements
Trustworthiness of a data quality result
Degree to which the sample used has produced a result which is representative of the data within the data quality scope
Expected or tested uniformity of the results obtained for a data quality evaluation
Elements that have not been in the dataset
Elements that are duplicated in the dataset
Incorrectly classified features

measure.source: GVQ (boolean )ISO 19157 Id.60 (count), Id.61 (rate), Id.62 (confusion matrix, count), Id.63 (confusion matrix, rate), Id.64 (Kappa coefficient)

desc.eng: Elements that are knowns to be in the ground truth and has not been recorded in the dataset and are missing

furtherInformation.eng: It is focuses on feature data where a feature has been ignored, such as a landmark like a church or a bridge that was overlooked and is not in the data

desc.eng: Indicator showing that a specific class is missing in the data

measure.example: A class 'boreal forest' is not present in the classified image. In situ data (ground truth) suggest that boreal forest is present in the scene extent

furtherInformation.eng: It is focuses on a value class (from the legend class collection in a classified imagery product) that is not present in the data. It is still possible that this is not a error and the is not really present in this scene and needs to be validated with ground truth to be considered an error

desc.eng: This quality measure indicates if there is absence of data for some reason that made impossible to get data in this area. In the case that the measure is provided as a pixel level quality, the resulting parameters are presented in the form of a data mask
The 'reason' provides the reason the value is marked as nodata. Possible values are 'anomalous', 'not acquired', 'unknown value', etc

furtherInformation.eng: Typically used in imagery to mark pixels that has a value that does not represent a correct measurement. Can be reported as a boolean per pixel or a percentage of 'nodata' pixels in an scene

desc.eng: This quality measure indicates if a data has the presence of some detected as anomalous such as snow or cloud. In the case that the measure is provided as a pixel level quality, the resulting parameters are presented in the form of a data mask
The 'reason' provides the reason the value is marked as flag. Possible values are 'snow', 'cloud', 'shadow', etc

furtherInformation.eng: Typically used in imagery to mark pixels that show 'snow' instead of 'land' behind, covered by clouds, are in the shadow of a cloud, etc. It c an be reported as a boolean per pixel or a percentage of 'flagged' pixels in an scene. This metrics is particularly relevant when building big mosaics of several scenes where, despite the efforts of the producer, some parts of the mosaic area are covered by any of the scenes and result in nodata values. This metrics is particularly relevant when building big mosaics of several scenes where, despite the efforts of the producer, some parts of the mosaic area cannot be covered with better scenes and still contain snow, cloud, shodows or other artefacts

desc.eng: Elements compliant or non-compliant with the rules of the relevant conceptuals schema

measure.source: ISO 19157: Id.8 + Id.9 (boolean), Id.10 + GVQ (count), Id.12 + Id.13 (rate)

desc.eng: Elements that overlap in an invalid way
Indication of if an item is conformance or not with a rule

measure.example: List of attributes assigned to a geometric object (e.g. polygon)

desc.eng: Elements in conflict with the physical structure
Elements with faulty point-curve connection
Elements undershooting
Elements overshooting
Elements that are slivers
Elements that self intersect in an invalid way
Elements that are overlapping with themselves

Mean value of the positional uncertainties for a set of positions where the positional uncertainties are defined as the distance between a measured position and what is considered as the corresponding true position

For a set of points where the distance does not exceed a defined threshold, the arithmetical average of distances between their measured positions and what is considered as the corresponding true positions
Shall be 'below'
Bias of the positions for a set of positions where the positional uncertainties are defined as the deviation between a measured position and what is considered as the corresponding true position

Number of positional uncertainties above a given threshold for a set of positions. The errors are defined as the distance between a measured position and what is considered as the corresponding true position
Symmetrical square matrix with variances of point coordinates on the main diagonal and covariances between these coordinates as off-diagonal elements
2D ellipse with the two main axes indicating the direction and magnitude of the highest and the lowest uncertainty of a 2D point
Half lenght of the interval defined by an upper and a lower limit, in which the true value lies with a certain probability
Standard deviation, where the true value is not estimated from the observations but known a priori

name.eng: Absolute linear error at 90% significance level. Alternative 1

desc.eng: Absolute vertical accuracy of the data's coordinates, expressed in terms of linear error at 90% probability given that a bias is present

name.eng: Absolute linear error at 90% significance level. Alternative 2

desc.eng: Absolute vertical accuracy of the data's coordinates, expressed in terms of linear error at 90% probability given that a bias is present
Radius describing a circle, in which the true point location lies with a certain probability

name.eng: Absolute circular error at 90% significance level. Alternative 1

desc.eng: Absolute horizontal accuracy of the data's coordinates, expressed in terms of circular error at 90% probability given that a bias is present

name.eng: Absolute circular error at 90% significance level. Alternative 2

desc.eng: Absolute horizontal accuracy of the data's coordinates, expressed in terms of circular error at 90% probability given that a bias is present

Evaluation of the random errors of one relief feature to another in the same dataset or on the same map/chart. It is a function of the random errors in the two elevations with respect to a common vertical datum
Half lenght of the interval defined by an upper and a lower limit, in which the true value for the time instance lies with a certain probability

A list of items that can be classified by 2 criteria (e.g. in a Remote Sensing Hybrid classification training pixels are already classified in T themantic categories (by the use of training areas) but are also assigned to S spectral classes. In this case The RCMt is called Fidelity matrix and the RCMs is calles Representativity matrix)
Half length of the interval defined by an upper and a lower limit, in which the true value for the quantitative attribute lies with a certain probability

This quality measure indicates if a data produced by interpolation of other measures (e.g. interpolation of punctual measures) is out of range of the interpolated regions so it is in fact extrapolated. In the case that the measure is provided as a pixel level quality, the resulting parameters are presented in the form of a data mask
It represents a list of measured or predicted values, sometimes represented as xmi.
It represents a list of values considered to represent the truth, sometimes represented as xti.
Given a measured xmi coordinate and a xti considered to represent the truth, the arthimetic error for one dimensional positional values is calculated as:
Given a measured ymi coordinate and a yti considered to represent the truth, the arthimetic error for one dimensional positional values is calculated as:

name.eng: 1D differential error measure with a threshold X

desc.eng:
Given a measured xmi coordinate and a xti considered to represent the truth, the differential error for one dimensional positional values with a threshold is calculated as:

selecting values:
if level='above': |exi|>emax
if level='below': |exi|<emax

name.eng: 1D differential error measure with a threshold Y

desc.eng:
Given a measured ymi coordinate and a yti considered to represent the truth, the differential error for one dimensional positional values with a threshold is calculated as:

selecting values:
if level=above': |exi|>emax
if level='below': |exi|<emax

name.eng: 1D differential error measure with a threshold

desc.eng:
Given a measured hmi coordinate and a hti considered to represent the truth, the arthimetic error for one dimensional positional values is calculated as:

selecting the values:
if level='above': SQRT(ehi2+ehi2)>emax
if level='below': SQRT(ehi2+ehi2)<emax

where "h" repensents a generic variable that is compared with a reference.

name.eng: 2D differential error measure with a threshold

desc.eng:
Given a measured xmi and ymi coordinate and a xti and yti, considered to represent the truth, the arthimetic errors for two dimensional positional values are calculated as:

selecting the values:
if level='above': SQRT(exi2+eyi2)>emax
if level='below': SQRT(exi2+eyi2)<emax

name.eng: 3D differential error measure with a threshold

desc.eng:
Given a measured xmi, ymi and zmi coordinate and a xti, yti and zti, considered to represent the truth, the arthimetic errors for three dimensional positional values are calculated as:

selecting the values:
if level='above': SQRT(exi2+eyi2+ezi2)>emax
if level='below': SQRT(exi2+eyi2+ezi2)<emax
Given a measured xmi and ymi coordinate and a xti and yti, considered to represent the truth, the diagonal error for two dimensional positional values are calculated as:

A random sample is a set of independent realisations, x_i, drawn from a probability distribution p(x) (or alternatively a population where every member has an equal chance of being drawn, but is randomly selected). The sample will typically be obtained using some form of simulation algorithm for base distributions using a random number generator of some sort. For more complex probability distributions they might typically be obtained using Monte Carlo methods or Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods. It is possible that some form of weighting is given to each realisation, for example derived from an importance sampling method, such as a particle filter. For finite samples there will be some induced sampling error
(optional) provides a textual description of the method used to obtain the samples

categories.eng: sample, continuous variables, ordinal variables, categorical variables, multivariate

domain.XMLSchema:
<!-- Element -->
<xs:element name="RandomSample" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSample">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:RandomSampleType"/>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

<!-- Complex type -->
<xs:complexType name="RandomSampleType">
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:AbstractSampleType">
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element ref="un:Realisation" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
</xs:sequence>
</xs:extension>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
domain.XMLExample:
<!-- Multiple realisations / samples -->
<un:RandomSample xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:samplingMethodDescription>Importance sampler with uniform proposal distribution</un:samplingMethodDescription>
<un:Realisation id="ID">
<un:weight>0.5</un:weight>
<un:values>3.14 6.28 9.42</un:values>
</un:Realisation>
<un:Realisation id="ID">
<un:weight>0.25</un:weight>
<un:values>3.14 6.28 9.42</un:values>
</un:Realisation>
<un:Realisation id="ID">
<un:weight>0.25</un:weight>
<un:values>3.14 6.28 9.42</un:values>
</un:Realisation>
</un:RandomSample>
domain.JSONExample:
// Multiple realisations / samples
{"RandomSample":{"samplingMethodDescription":"Importance sampler with uniform proposal distribution","realisations":[{"values":[3.14,6.28,9.42],"id":"ID","weight":0.5},{"values":[3.14,6.28,9.42],"id":"ID","weight":0.25},{"values":[3.14,6.28,9.42],"id":"ID","weight":0.25}]}}
domain.APIExample:
// Multiple value declaration
RandomSample rs = new RandomSample(new Realisation[] {new Realisation(new double[] {3.14, 6.28, 9.42}, 0.5, "ID"), new Realisation(new double[] {3.14, 6.28, 9.42}, 0.25, "ID"), new Realisation(new double[] {3.14, 6.28, 9.42}, 0.25, "ID")}, "Importance sampler with uniform proposal distribution");

// Parsing from an XML file
XMLParser xml = new XMLParser();
RandomSample rs = (RandomSample)xml.parse(new File("random-sample.xml"));

// Parsing from a JSON file
JSONParser json = new JSONParser();
RandomSample rs = (RandomSample)json.parse(new File("random-sample.json"));

// Encoding to an XML file
XMLEncoder xEncoder = new XMLEncoder();
xEncoder.encode(rs, new File("random-sample.xml"));

// Encoding to a JSON file
JSONEncoder jEncoder = new JSONEncoder();
jEncoder.encode(rs, new File("random-sample.json"));
domain.ValueConstraints: values: any real number or any integer or any category which can be vectors for multivariate distributions

desc.eng: Number of items
boolean
int
real, attribute: max(real)

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0"
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>

<element name="Items" type="qml:ItemsType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="ItemsType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<choice>
<element name="indicator" type="qml:BooleanNumbersType"/>
<element name="count" type="un:NaturalNumbersType"/>
<element name="rate" type="qml:RateType"/>
</choice>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
Missing Quality Measure example

<un:StatisticsCollection xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.qualitymlorg/schemas/qualityml/1.0/qualityml.xsd">

Indicator

<qml:Items>
<qml:indicator>true</qml:indicator>
</qml:Items>

Count

<qml:Items>
<qml:count>5</qml:count>
</qml:Items>

Rate

<qml:Items>
<qml:rate max="100">66</qml:rate>
</qml:Items>

desc.eng: In a confusion matrix, off-diagonal column elements represent ground truth items of other classes that were included in a certain classification class. Such errors are also known as errors of commission or inclusion.

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0"
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<complexType name="ConfusionMatrixDerivatesType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="qml:AbstractMetricsAggregationType">
<sequence>
<element ref="qml:CommissionError" minOccurs="0"/>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng:
FPR = FP/N = FP/(FP+TN)

where FP = false positive, TN = true negative

In a confusion matrix, off-diagonal row elements represent ground truth items of a certain class which were excluded from that class during classification. Such errors are also known as errors of omission or exclusion.

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="OmissionError" type="qml:OmissionErrorType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="OmissionErrorType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="actualCategories" type="un:CategoricalValuesType"/>
<element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng: Mean value of the uncertainties exi of a number of measures (N) is calculated as:
Mean value of the uncertainties exi and eyi of a number of measures (N) is calculated as:
Mean value of the uncertainties exi, eyi and ezi of a number of measures (N) is calculated as:
Mean value of the individual errors. For a number of measured positions that depends on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured(N). It is calculated as:
Mean value of the uncertainties exi normalized by the true values xti of a number of measures (N) is calculated as:

Given d univariate random variables (x1,...,xd), the covariance matrix of (x1,...,xd) is the d X d matrix C whose elements Cij are the covariance between xi and xj. That is, Cij=E[(xi-E[xi])(xj-E[xj])]. In particular, the diagonal elements Cii are the variances of the xi. The matrix is stored in row major format in QualityML/UncertML. It is possible that future versions of them will have specialised types for simpler covariance matrices, such as sparse, outer product, block and n-diagonal matrix types.
d (dimension) the number of random variables

metric.XMLSchema:
<!-- Element -->
<xs:element name="CovarianceMatrix" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:CovarianceMatrixType"/>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

<!-- Complex type -->
<xs:complexType name="CovarianceMatrixType">
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</xs:sequence>
<xs:attribute name="dimension" type="un:naturalNumber" use="required"/>
</xs:extension>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
metric.APIExample:
// Multiple value declaration
CovarianceMatrix cm = new CovarianceMatrix(2, new double[] {3.14, 0.0, 0.0, 3.14});

// Parsing from an XML file
XMLParser xml = new XMLParser();
CovarianceMatrix cm = (CovarianceMatrix)xml.parse(new File("covariance-matrix.xml"));

// Parsing from a JSON file
JSONParser json = new JSONParser();
CovarianceMatrix cm = (CovarianceMatrix)json.parse(new File("covariance-matrix.json"));

// Encoding to an XML file
XMLEncoder xEncoder = new XMLEncoder();
xEncoder.encode(cm, new File("covariance-matrix.xml"));

// Encoding to a JSON file
JSONEncoder jEncoder = new JSONEncoder();
jEncoder.encode(cm, new File("covariance-matrix.json"));

desc.eng:
2D ellipse with the two main axes indicating the direction and magnitude of the highest and the lowest uncertainty of a 2D point

The process of calculating this statistic starts defining a covariance matrix.
in multiple values

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0"
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="ConfidenceEllipse" type="qml:ConfidenceEllipseType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="ConfidenceEllipseType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="a" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
<element name="b" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
<element name="a_angle" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</sequence>
<attribute name="confidence" use="required">
<simpleType>
<restriction base="double">
<pattern value="0.683"/>
<pattern value="0.95"/>
<pattern value="0.99"/>
</restriction>
</simpleType>
</attribute>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng: The probability of a measurement to lie inside a confidence interval expressed in the half-length distance
Extends http://www.uncertml.org/statistics/confidence-interval
value to indicate the confidence level (in the range [0,1]). Typical values are 0.5 0.683 0.9, 0.95 0.99 0.998
Measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values actually observed
Measure of the differences between 2D values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values actually observed
Measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values actually observed

Measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the values actually observed.

NRMSE = RMSE / (xmax - xmin)

where xmax = maximum observed value; xmin = minimum observed value

name.eng: Coefficient of variation root mean square error

desc.eng:
Measure of the differences between values predicted by a model or an estimator and the mean of the values actually observed.

CV(RMSE) = RMSE / MEAN

where MEAN = the mean of the observed values

name.eng: Absolute linear error at 90% significance level. Alternative 1

desc.eng: The absolute vertical accuracy of the data’s coordinates, expressed in terms of linear error at 90% probability given that a bias is present.

name.eng: Absolute linear error at 90% significance level. Alternative 2

desc.eng:
The absolute vertical accuracy of the data’s coordinates, expressed in
terms of linear error at 90% probability given that a bias is present.
Radius describing a circle, in which the true point location lies with a certain probability
value to indicate the confidence level (in the range [0,1])

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
 xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
 xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
 elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
 <element name='CircularError' substitutionGroup='un:AbstractSummaryStatistic'>
<complexType>
<complexContent>
<extension base='qml:ContinuousValuesSummaryStatisticType'>
<attribute name='level' use='required'>
<simpleType>
<restriction base='double'>
<minInclusive value='0.0'/>
<maxInclusive value='1.0'/>
</restriction>
</simpleType>
</attribute>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>
</element>

name.eng: Absolute circular error at 90% significance level. Alternative 1

desc.eng: The absolute horizontal accuracy of the data’s coordinates, expressed in terms of circular error at 90% probability given that a bias is present.

name.eng: Absolute cirular error at 90% significance level. Alternative 2

desc.eng: The absolute horizontal accuracy of the data’s coordinates, expressed in terms of circular error at 90% probability given that a bias is present.

Evaluation of the random errors of one relief feature to another in the same dataset or on the same map/chart. It is a function of the random errors in the two elevations with respect to a common vertical datum.
Evaluation of the random errors in the horizontal position of one feature to another in the same dataset or on the same map/chart.

Matrix that indicates the number of items of class (i; the truth) classified as class (j; predicted).

The confusion matrix is a NxN matrix with N columns and N rows. N denotes the number of classes under consideration.
MCM (i,j) = ( # items of class (i) classified as class (j) )
The diagonal elements of the confusion matrix contain the correctly classified items, and the off diagonal elements contain the number of misclassification errors.

Extends http://www.uncertml.org/metrics/confusion-matrix adding a max value

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="ConfusionMatrix" type="qml:ConfusionMatrixType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="ConfusionMatrixType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="actualCategories" type="un:CategoricalValuesType"/>
<element name="predictedCategories" type="un:CategoricalValuesType"/>
<element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</sequence>
<attribute name="max" type="qml:nonNegativeRealNumber"/>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<un:StatisticsCollection xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.qualitymlorg/schemas/qualityml/1.0/qualityml.xsd">
<qml:ConfusionMatrix max="100">
<qml:actualCategories>A B C</qml:actualCategories>
<qml:predictedCategories>A B C</qml:predictedCategories>
<qml:values>
87   1  12
 5  88   7
 8  11  81
</qml:values>
</qml:ConfusionMatrix>

desc.eng:
Matrix that indicates the number of items of class (i) classified as class (j) divided by the number of items of class (i). The confusion matrix is a NxN matrix with N columns and N rows. N denotes the number of classes under consideration.


RMCM (i,j) = [ # items of class (i) classified as class (j)] / (# items of class (i)] x 100%

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="RelativeConfusionMatrix" type="qml:RelativeConfusionMatrixType" substitutionGroup="qml:ConfusionMatrix"/>
<complexType name="RelativeConfusionMatrixType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="qml:ConfusionMatrixType">
<attribute name="category">
<simpleType>
<restriction base="string">
<enumeration value="actual" />
<enumeration value="predicted" />
</restriction>
</simpleType>
</attribute>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<un:StatisticsCollection xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.qualitymlorg/schemas/qualityml/1.0/qualityml.xsd">
<qml:RelativeConfusionMatrix max="100">
<qml:actualCategories>Red Green Blue</qml:actualCategories>
<qml:predictedCategories>Red Green Blue</qml:predictedCategories>
<qml:values>
1.57 3.14 6.28
1.57 3.14 6.28
1.57 3.14 6.28
</qml:values>
</qml:RelativeConfusionMatrix>

desc.eng: Coefficient to quantify the proportion of agreement of assignments to classes by removing misclassifications

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<simpleType name="kappaCoefficientValueArray">
<list itemType="qml:kappaCoefficientValue"/>
</simpleType>
<element name="KappaCoefficient" type="qml:KappaCoefficientType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="KappaCoefficientType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="values" type="qml:kappaCoefficientValueArray"/>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng: Is the fraction of correctly classified items with regard to all items of the ground truth class (rows). For each class of ground truth items, the number of correctly classified items is divided by the total number of ground truth or test items of that class.

Is the fraction of correctly classified items with regard to all items classified as this class in the classified image. For each class in the classified image (column), the number of correctly classified items is divided by the total number of items which were classified as this class.
The average reliability is calculated as the sum of the reliability values divided by the number of classes in the test set.
The average accuracy is calculated as the sum of the accuracy values divided by the number of classes in the test set.
Is calculated as the total number of correctly classified items (diagonal elements) divided by the total number of test items.

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<complexType name="ConfusionMatrixDerivatesType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="qml:AbstractMetricsAggregationType">
<sequence>
<element ref="qml:OverallAccuracy" minOccurs="0"/>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng: In statistics the Absolute frequency of an event i is the number ni of times the event occurred in an experiment or study. These frequencies are often graphically represented in histograms.

A receiver operating characteristic (ROC), or simply ROC curve, is a graphical plot which illustrates the performance of a binary classifier system as its discrimination threshold is varied. It is created by plotting the fraction of true positives out of the total actual positives (TPR = true positive rate) vs. the fraction of false positives out of the total actual negatives (FPR = false positive rate), at various threshold settings.

The ROC is also known as a relative operating characteristic curve, because it is a comparison of two operating characteristics (TPR and FPR) as the criterion changes.

furtherInformation.eng:
http://metaoptimize.com/qa/questions/988/simple-explanation-of-area-under-the-roc-curve
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver_operating_characteristic

Fawcett T (2006) An introduction to ROC analysis: https://cours.etsmtl.ca/sys828/REFS/A1/Fawcett_PRL2006.pdf

desc.eng: The coefficient of determination is commonly represented by the letter r2 and may be referred to as the square of the sample correlation coefficient or the sample Pearson correlation coefficient. We can obtain a formula for r2 by substituting estimates of the covariances and variances based on a sample into the formula. The expression for r2 is:

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
 xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0"
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0"
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="CoefficientOfDetermination" type="qml:CoefficientOfDeterminationType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="CoefficientOfDeterminationType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="values" type="un:ProbabilityValuesType"/>
</sequence>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType

desc.eng:
The correlation between two random sampled variables x and y is the extent to which these variable vary together in a linear fashion. It is characterised by the coefficient
also equivalent to .
Note this is strictly not a description of uncertainty, but it can be useful to represent the correlation between two variables. Generally a covariance specification would be preferred since this describes the uncertainty.

furtherInformation.eng: Extracted from UncertML http://www.uncertml.org/statistics/correlation. See also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coefficient_of_determination and http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Correlation.html, http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CorrelationCoefficient.html

metric.XMLSchema:
<!-- Element -->
<xs:element name="Correlation" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:CorrelationType"/>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

<!-- Complex type -->
<xs:complexType name="CorrelationType">
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element name="values" type="un:NormalisedValuesType"/>
</xs:sequence>
</xs:extension>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<!-- Single value -->
<un:Correlation xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>-1.0</un:values>
</un:Correlation>

<!-- Multiple values -->
<un:Correlation xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>-1.0 0.0 1.0</un:values>
</un:Correlation>
metric.APIExample:
// Single value declaration
Correlation c = new Correlation(-1.0);

// Multiple value declaration
Correlation c = new Correlation(new double[] {-1.0, 0.0, 1.0});

// Parsing from an XML file
XMLParser xml = new XMLParser();
Correlation c = (Correlation)xml.parse(new File("correlation.xml"));

// Parsing from a JSON file
JSONParser json = new JSONParser();
Correlation c = (Correlation)json.parse(new File("correlation.json"));

// Encoding to an XML file
XMLEncoder xEncoder = new XMLEncoder();
xEncoder.encode(c, new File("correlation.xml"));

// Encoding to a JSON file
JSONEncoder jEncoder = new JSONEncoder();
jEncoder.encode(c, new File("correlation.json"));
metric.ValueConstraints: value: any real number in the range [-1.0 - 1.0] (inclusive)

desc.eng:
Consider two classification models which assigns eath item to one category out of T and one category out of S, for instance a model which assigns images of a handwritten character to one of the 26 alphabetical characters ('a', 'b', 'c'...) and one of the S Greek alphabetical (alfa, beta, gamma...). The correspondence matrix is an T x S matrix which matches the first model categories (rows) against the second model categories (columns).

CM(t,s) = ( # items classified as class (t) in the first model classified and class (s) in the second model )

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="CorrespondenceMatrix" type="qml:CorrespondenceMatrixType" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic"/>
<complexType name="CorrespondenceMatrixType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<sequence>
<element name="categoriesT" type="un:CategoricalValuesType"/>
<element name="categoriesS" type="un:CategoricalValuesType"/>
<element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</sequence>
<attribute name="max" type="qml:nonNegativeRealNumber"/>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<un:StatisticsCollection xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.qualitymlorg/schemas/qualityml/1.0/qualityml.xsd">
<qml:CorrespondenceMatrix max="100">
<qml:categoriesT>Red Green Blue</qml:categoriesT>
<qml:categoriesS>Red Green Blue</qml:categoriesS>
<qml:values>1.57 3.14 6.28 1.57 3.14 6.28 1.57 3.14 6.28</qml:values>
</qml:CorrespondenceMatrix>

desc.eng:
False discovery rate (FDR) control is a statistical method used in multiple hypothesis testing to correct for multiple comparisons. In a list of findings (i.e. studies where the null-hypotheses are rejected), FDR procedures are designed to control the expected proportion of incorrectly rejected null hypotheses ("false discoveries"). FDR controlling procedures exert a less stringent control over false discovery compared to familywise error rate (FWER) procedures (such as the Bonferroni correction), which seek to reduce the probability of even one false discovery, as opposed to the expected proportion of false discoveries. Thus FDR procedures have greater power at the cost of increased rates of type I errors, i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis of no effect when it should be accepted.

FDR = FP/(FP+TP)

where FP = false positive, TP = true positive

The Gini coefficient is a single number aimed at measuring how far a country’s wealth distribution deviates from totally equal distribution of productivity. It's usually defined mathematically based on the Lorenz curve, which plots the proportion of the total income of the population (y axis) that is cumulatively earned by the bottom x of the population. If all people have non-negative income, the Gini coefficient can theoretically range from 0 (complete equality) to 1 (complete inequality); it is sometimes expressed as a percentage ranging between 0 and 100.

where xi is the wealth or income of person i, and there are n persons.

Introduced concept in the study, related to fidelity and promiscuity. It states the number of cathegories with a fidelity higher than a determined threshold for each statistical class in a hybrid classification consisting on two steps: unsupervised classification/introduction of training areas

The Matthews correlation coefficient is used in machine learning as a measure of the quality of binary (two-class) classifications. It takes into account true and false positives and negatives and is generally regarded as a balanced measure which can be used even if the classes are of very different sizes. The MCC is in essence a correlation coefficient between the observed and predicted binary classifications; it returns a value between −1 and +1. A coefficient of +1 represents a perfect prediction, 0 no better than random prediction and −1 indicates total disagreement between prediction and observation. The statistic is also known as the phi coefficient.
In a correspondence matrix, is the number of values in a class (s, a row) conformance with a certain threshold..

In statistics and diagnostic testing, the positive predictive value, or precision rate is the proportion of positive test results that are true positives (such as correct diagnoses). It is a critical measure of the performance of a diagnostic method, as it reflects the probability that a positive test reflects the underlying condition being tested for. Its value does however depend on the prevalence of the outcome of interest, which may be unknown for a particular target population. The PPV can be derived using Bayes' theorem.

PPV = TP/(TP+FP)

where FP = false positive, TP = true positive
In a correspondence matrix, is the number of non-zero values in a class (s, a row).
The ratio between the number of items in the modal category and the total number of items.

furtherInformation.eng: In a classification of n classes, it can be used to decide if the modal class is representative enough; the modal class will be disregarded if it is below a threshold.

desc.eng:
Given set of items classified by two different criteria, the relative correspondence matrix is an S x T matrix which matches the first classification (rows) against the second classification (columns) but relative to the total of items in a class of the first or the second classification.

RCMs(s,t) = (# items classified as class (s) in the first classification and as class (t) in the second classification) / # items classified as class (s) in the first classification


RCMt(s,t) = (# items classified as class (s) in the first classification and as class (t) in the second classification) / # items classified as class (t) in the second classification
relative to s (RCMs) or t (RCMt)

metric.XMLSchema:
<schema xmlns:qml="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" 
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" targetNamespace="http://www.qualityml.org/1.0" 
elementFormDefault="qualified" attributeFormDefault="unqualified">
<import namespace="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0" schemaLocation="../../uncertml/2.0/uncertml.xsd"/>
<element name="RelativeCorrespondenceMatrix" type="qml:RelativeCorrespondenceMatrixType" substitutionGroup="qml:CorrespondenceMatrix"/>
<complexType name="RelativeCorrespondenceMatrixType">
<complexContent>
<extension base="qml:CorrespondenceMatrixType">
<attribute name="category">
<simpleType>
<restriction base="string">
<enumeration value="T"/>
<enumeration value="S"/>
</restriction>
</simpleType>
</attribute>
</extension>
</complexContent>
</complexType>

desc.eng:
The relative frequency of an event is the absolute frequency normalized by the total number of events:

The values of fi for all events i can be plotted to produce a frequency distribution.

In the case when ni=0 for certain i, pseudocounts can be added.

Sensitivity relates to the test's ability to identify positive results. The sensitivity of a test is the proportion of people that are known to have the disease who test positive for it. This can also be written as:

furtherInformation.eng:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity

Fawcett T (2006) An introduction to ROC analysis: https://cours.etsmtl.ca/sys828/REFS/A1/Fawcett_PRL2006.pdf

desc.eng: Specificity relates to the test's ability to identify negative results. The specificity of a test is defined as the proportion of patients that are known not to have the disease who will test negative for it. This can also be written as:

furtherInformation.eng:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity

Fawcett T (2006) An introduction to ROC analysis: https://cours.etsmtl.ca/sys828/REFS/A1/Fawcett_PRL2006.pdf

desc.eng: The standard deviation of a distribution or population is the square root of its variance and is given by where . The population standard deviation is given by where , xi represents with i'th observation of the quantity x in the population of size n. The standard deviation is a widely used measure of the variability or dispersion since it is reported in the natural units of the quantity being considered. Note that if a finite sample of a population has been used then the sample standard deviation is the appropriate unbiased estimator to use.

metric.XMLSchema:
<!-- Element -->
<xs:element name="StandardDeviation" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:StandardDeviationType"/>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

<!-- Complex type -->
<xs:complexType name="StandardDeviationType">
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</xs:sequence>
</xs:extension>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<!-- Single value -->
<un:StandardDeviation xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>3.14</un:values>
</un:StandardDeviation>

<!-- Multiple values -->
<un:StandardDeviation xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>3.14 6.28 9.42</un:values>
</un:StandardDeviation>
metric.APIExample:
// Single value declaration
StandardDeviation v = new StandardDeviation(3.14);

// Multiple value declaration
StandardDeviation v = new StandardDeviation(new double[] {3.14, 6.28, 9.42});

// Parsing from an XML file
XMLParser xml = new XMLParser();
StandardDeviation v = (StandardDeviation)xml.parse(new File("StandardDeviation.xml"));

// Parsing from a JSON file
JSONParser json = new JSONParser();
StandardDeviation v = (StandardDeviation)json.parse(new File("StandardDeviation.json"));

// Encoding to an XML file
XMLEncoder xEncoder = new XMLEncoder();
xEncoder.encode(v, new File("StandardDeviation.xml"));

// Encoding to a JSON file
JSONEncoder jEncoder = new JSONEncoder();
jEncoder.encode(v, new File("StandardDeviation.json"));

desc.eng: The variance of a random quantity (or distribution) is the average value of the square of the deviation of that variable from its mean, given by where . The complete population variance is given by where , xi represents with i'th observation of the quantity x in the population of size n. This is the estimator of the population variance and should be replaced by the sample variance when using samples of finite size.

metric.XMLSchema:
<!-- Element -->
<xs:element name="Variance" substitutionGroup="un:AbstractSummaryStatistic">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:VarianceType"/>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

<!-- Complex type -->
<xs:complexType name="VarianceType">
<xs:complexContent>
<xs:extension base="un:AbstractSummaryStatisticType">
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element name="values" type="un:ContinuousValuesType"/>
</xs:sequence>
</xs:extension>
</xs:complexContent>
</xs:complexType>
metric.XMLExample:
<!-- Single value -->
<un:Variance xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>3.14</un:values>
</un:Variance>

<!-- Multiple values -->
<un:Variance xmlns:un="http://www.uncertml.org/2.0">
<un:values>3.14 6.28 9.42</un:values>
</un:Variance>
metric.APIExample:
// Single value declaration
Variance v = new Variance(3.14);

// Multiple value declaration
Variance v = new Variance(new double[] {3.14, 6.28, 9.42});

// Parsing from an XML file
XMLParser xml = new XMLParser();
Variance v = (Variance)xml.parse(new File("variance.xml"));

// Parsing from a JSON file
JSONParser json = new JSONParser();
Variance v = (Variance)json.parse(new File("variance.json"));

// Encoding to an XML file
XMLEncoder xEncoder = new XMLEncoder();
xEncoder.encode(v, new File("variance.xml"));

// Encoding to a JSON file
JSONEncoder jEncoder = new JSONEncoder();
jEncoder.encode(v, new File("variance.json"));

MetricMatrix.measure_obs: List of attributes assigned to a geometric object (e.g. polygon)

MetricMatrix.observations: A Remote sensing hybrid classification method uses the Fidelity matrix to assigns a spectral class to the thematic class which the highest fidelity. A fidelity and representative thresholds may be defined; therefore items in spectral classes in which all fidelities are is below a threshold will not be assigned to any thematic class and therefore resulting in non-classified items (NODATA pixels) and thematic classes in which all representatibities are is below a threshold are discarded.

For the Half-lengthConfidenceInterval the common confidence intervals are: 50%, 68.3%, 90%, 95%, 99%, 99.8%
